awd_titl_txt: Bimetallic Janus Nanocrystals and Their Derivatives
awd_abstract_narration:
Assemblies of metal atoms with well-ordered structures in the size range of ~10 nanometers are known as nanocrystals. Controlling the spatial distributions of different metal atoms in nanocrystals offers a simple and versatile way to tailor their structures and properties. Such tailoring has the potential to vastly expand their utility as catalysts in the production of important chemicals and pharmaceuticals as well as processes used for conversion of energy and protection of the environment. In this project, Dr. Younan Xia of the Georgia Institute of Technology and Dr. Manos Mavrikakis of the University of Wisconsin-Madison are developing a bimetallic system, in which the two metals are spatially separated from each other by an interface to form nanocrystals with a Janus structure. The bimetallic Janus nanocrystals offer a broad range of unique properties and applications, including the tuning of optical response and the enhancement of catalytic activity and/or selectivity for specific chemical products. By switching to bimetallic Janus nanocrystals and their derivatives, one can substantially reduce the amount of precious metal in a nanocrystal while potentially improving the performance, enabling Society to achieve cost-effective and sustainable use of precious metals, some of the scarcest elements in the Earth's crust. However, there are only a very limited number of reports on bimetallic Janus nanocrystals, primarily due to the lack of mechanistic understanding and experimental control for their chemical synthesis. As a major requirement for the formation of bimetallic Janus nanocrystals, the atoms of one metal can only be deposited at a single site on the surface of a nanocrystal made of another metal and this particular pattern of deposition must be maintained throughout the growth process. The PIs integrate experimental studies and computational modeling in their development of predictable, deterministic, and robust synthesis of bimetallic Janus nanocrystals. They are also contributing to the preparation of a skilled workforce for science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines through active engagement of graduate and undergraduate students in this collaborative, multidisciplinary research, as well as curriculum enrichment and development. The investigators are fully committed to promoting diversity in higher education by engaging underrepresented groups into this research project. 

With funding from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular & Nanochemistry (MSN) Program of the Chemistry Division, Drs. Xia and Mavrikakis are developing a new knowledge base for the design and deterministic synthesis of bimetallic Janus nanocrystals. They are deriving the exact range of initial reduction rate needed for achieving nucleation and growth from a single site on each individual nanocrystal and thus generating a Janus structure. They are also investigating the thermal stability of the Janus nanocrystals with respect to atomic inter-diffusion and surface diffusion. As for applications, the Janus nanocrystals are explored as building blocks for colloidal self-assembly and as sacrificial templates for the fabrication of metal nanoboxes with a single, well-defined hole on the surface, preferably located at one of the vertices. Such nanoboxes, when made of platinum, can serve as a highly active and durable catalyst towards oxygen reduction, a reaction key to the operation of hydrogen-based fuel cells. Along with the experimental studies, computational modeling is used to explain the trends and mechanisms involved in the syntheses, as well as the catalysis taking place on some of the bimetallic nanocrystals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Controlling the spatial distributions of different metals in a nanocrystal offers a powerful method to engineer its electronic structure and catalytic properties, opening the door to the development of more effective catalysts vital to applications such as energy conversion, chemical production, and environmental protection. During this project, the investigators developed and explored an unique bimetallic system, in which the two metals are separated from each other by an interface to generate nanocrystals with a Janus configuration. The side-by-side arrangement of two different metals offers a simple and versatile platform to tailor the catalytic and optical properties of nanocrystals.

Intellectual Merit. The investigators established a knowledge base for the rational design and deterministic synthesis of bimetallic Janus nanocrystals with well-defined elemental distributions and surface structures. Through an integration of experimental and computational studies, the investigators demonstrated the pivotal role of reduction kinetics as a quantitative knob to achieve rational, robust, and even predictable synthesis of bimetallic Janus nanocrystals. As a notable example, the investigators demonstrated the rational synthesis of palladium-copper Janus nanocrystals with well-controlled surface structures through site-selected growth of copper from palladium icosahedral seeds. At a slow reduction rate,  the copper atoms can be directed to nucleate and grow from one of the 12 equivalent vertices on the seed for the production of a penta-twinned Janus nanocrystal in the shape of pentagonal bipyramid or decahedron. At a fast reduction rate, in contrast, the copper atoms grow from one of the 30 equivalent edges for the generation of a singly-twinned, truncated bitetrahedron. The separation of copper and palladium into a Janus configuration and the presence of twin boundaries on the surface made these bimetallic nanocrystals effective catalysts toward the electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide. Computational studies confirmed that the carbon monoxide formed on the palladium region during electrolysis could migrate to the copper region on the same particle for subsequent carbon-carbon coupling, promoting the formation of more valuable chemicals. This work not only offers insights into the rational fabrication of bimetallic Janus nanocrystals with the desired surface composition and structure for a specific catalytic reaction but also sheds light on the site-selected growth of bimetallic nanocrystals with new shapes or morphologies by quantitatively manipulating the reduction kinetics. The investigators published more than 30 papers in peer-review journals, including a major review article on the subject of bimetallic Janus nanocrystals.

Broader Impact. The investigators contributed to the preparation of a skilled workforce for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics disciplines through active engagement of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in this multidisciplinary research, in addition to the enrichment and development of curriculum. The investigators promoted diversity in higher education by engaging women, minorities, and other underrepresented groups into this research project. Specifically, this project provided training to nine Ph.D. students (five females, six of them have graduated) and engaged four undergraduate students (including one female and one Hispanic female) and one high school student (female). Furthermore, the investigators established collaborations with research groups from many other organizations, including one group from the Oak Ridge National Laboratory to further explore the unique properties of the Janus nanocrystals. The mechanistic understanding achieved during this project has enabled the rational synthesis of metal nanoparticles with enhanced properties for a variety of applications in energy conversion, chemical production, and environmental protection, contributing to the achievement of a sustainable society.
